Thought it was just a chemical company you know, some of the strongest, I mean, really strong disinfectants, like bleach or formaldehyde, and so once Mr. Jones really gets going and we can reopen some states you’ll be able to really attack this virus, and I mean really attack- perhaps kill- this virus. This, invisible enemy. Really that’s what it is. It’s invisible. But we’re taking a look at it and a lot of different things and I think the American people are really going to like what they see.

author: ObscureWhistle
body:
Extra Credits did a pretty good series on it.

I shit you not, the company could only send something like one ship per month, twelve ships per year to the entirety of the South American Ports. 

To compare, fleets of ships were being sent to India to simply maintain the supply and trade going on there - the company’s scheme was completely FUCKED.

But the company was like “it’s fine, everything’s fine” the stock value increased, the ENTIRE COUNTRY bought into it, LOANS were being taken to buy more shares! It got so huge that the government had to shut down private entrepreneurs because they were taking away from buying shares. RE: there was not enough money in circulation to allow for other startups because they needed all the money for this company that DOESNT ACTUALLY MAKE ANY MONEY!

And then it failed and everyone lost their stuff!

This is the second funniest shit I’ve ever heard of. 

The first was the Viking that killed his rival, let the guy’s head hang from his saddle, only to get an infection from the head’s buck-teeth and die three days later.

Now *that* is some autist level shit!

[South Sea Bubble](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL931Bkj5KLMtJ4AMegQtekqKcCy14FCec)

TLDR; 

1) Don’t cut off a guy’s head and tie it to a saddle bag - that’s disgusting and it’s not social distancing. 

2) Don’t take economic advice from a guy who’s know for: an apple falling on his head, creating a universal gravitational theory, and being COMPLETELY FUCKING INSANE! 

3) Finally, get a DNA for all your children. Hey, someone might be fucking your wife, but you won’t have to pay child support! Fuck the house, those monthly payments add up!

EDIT: For the memes (also, a moment of silence for me and all of the brothers who have STNG and EURN shares. We will rise again, someday).

author: LatinoMuyFinO
body:
Some Options:

BYND Calls: I shorted this today from $138 to $135. Could have made more if i had held til close but fuck it. They took a beating and am expecting a bounce back from the 132-133 level. I'll be going short term calls tomorrow for a quick scalp at open.

PTON Calls: Same as above \^ bounce back from the $40-41 level

DKNG: FOMO if you want. This thing could pop to $40 or drop to $30. I won't be touching this until at least another week or so. Risky af but mad tendiez if you guess the right direction (calls/puts)

COTY: Same as above, but I expect this will hold better than DKNG since its already near rock bottom prices. Might throw a few thousand at it tomorrow in calls.

SPY: i personally don't play SPY, but there is mad tendiez to be made if you get in calls at a dip (around the 295-297 range) or puts (around the 301-303 range).

CCL, RCL, NCLH: Easy plays to go long on a dip, Beaten up cruise stocks that have been forming new bottoms. Easy 2x 3x bagger if you get in before a large move up in the premarket. They seem a bit overheated lately though so I would be careful of a pullback soon, in which case go short term puts.

AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV, SAVE: Same as above

AAPL, MSFT, AMD, NVDA: Tech saw a big hit today, might be a good spot to buy the dip. I'll be watching closely tomorrow if we continue to fall in tech at open, then I'm buying the dip for sure.

BABA, TSM: GYNA stocks if you want i guess

&#x200B;

Good luck making your parents money back you fucking autist.

author: bewb_tewb
body:
The reason he said the stock is overpriced is largely due to the shutdown. 

Tesla has a lot of things priced in at this point. What isn’t priced in (right now) is the inability to build cars due to the shutdown. 

The real problem is that everything is overpriced right now. A record breaking unemployment report went out and the DOW still went up 400 points. 

Tesla, at this point, will never go bankrupt. Any company, be it Apple or google, would buy them instantly if they had the opportunity to swoop in. There’s a ton of reason to be optimistic about the future of the company regardless of all of this.

author: jpreeves
body:
> First of all, props to the CEO. Notwithstanding the management that led the company to where it is now, the way he's conducting the layoffs should be a gold standard to the many others soon to come.

Completely agree. Scanning down the list, these are actually sizable investments in departing workers. It's not only decent, it will read well—both as a PR move, and in recruiting top talent back should the opportunity arise. 

>Alumni Talent Directory — We will be launching a public-facing website to help teammates leaving find new jobs. Departing employees can opt-in to have profiles, resumes, and work samples accessible to potential employers. 
>Alumni Placement Team — For the remainder of 2020, a significant portion of Airbnb Recruiting will become an Alumni Placement Team. Recruiters that are staying with Airbnb will provide support to departing employees to help them find their next job.
>RiseSmart — We are offering four months of career services through RiseSmart, a company that specializes in career transition and job placement services. 
>Employee Offered Alumni Support — We are encouraging all remaining employees to opt-in to a program to assist departing teammates find their next role.
>Laptops — A computer is an important tool to find new work, so we are allowing everyone leaving to keep their Apple laptops.

author: LivinTheHiLife
body:
On April 17 I went all in on SPY puts and rode SPY down from $284 to 273. 

On April 29, I turned a $780 gamble into 3800 on Google $1350 5/8 FDs. 

The next day I lost 2800 of that on Apple calls on their ER. But, I made it all back and more that same day when Daddy Elon made his now infamous tweet (I have him on notification on twitter). 

Did puts on TSLA that instant with my remaining 1400 into about 5300. Lost some. Then did all in on calls yesterday into Baba. Which took me to $7,000. 

That same night I sold BABA calls I went in on NFLX calls when NFLX dropped like a rock in anticipation for DIS. Sold all NFLX calls at open for a total $3,500 gain resulting in my $10.5k total you see here now.

For some reason, i was so autistic in the heat of things I got marked as a pattern day trader today from a trade I didn't realize I made yesterday. So I'm locked out of RH for 90 days which is fantastic because it prevents me from losing this all so I get to keep these tendies. lol im so fucking dumb man it hurts.

author: wozza365
body:
Excel is a really interesting one, and actually points to just how good MS are at being backwards compatible.

Most of the longstanding bugs are well documented and understood, but are left in on purpose, even reprogramming to produce the same bugs to ensure compatibility with spreadsheets from 20 years ago that would break if the bug was fixed.

Most, including myself would argue that those old spreadsheets should either be updated or remain on an old Office version, but it's the path they've chosen to take and I think a lot of businesses love it compared to Apple dropping support for things almost overnight.

author: PillarsBliz
body:
I think it's an interesting question since I am familiarizing myself with companies.  Surely companies won't have their share price increase forever (just look at the crash this year), but some of the ones I expect will still be strong in 6 months would be:

* NVDA (despite the recent crash I think they'll at least stay strong, they have a good product, and they're in good financial shape)
* HD (I want to trade this, seems a very solid company for contractor / do it yourself / home install stuff)
* BBY (of all the consumer stores besides maybe Wal-mart, this seems in the best financial shape to survive?)
* DIS (Disney has been tremendously successful at adapting and surviving, and I expect their stock to recover hugely)
* MSFT (huge company, seems to be in good shape, if they die then we're in deep trouble everywhere since Windows is so ubiquitous)
* KO (good defensive stock, decent dividend)

If I had more money, I'd probably look at Apple, Amazon, and Tesla.

author: nckmiz
body:
The market was down 30% for a week or so. You think Berk can just deploy 60 billion the way you deploy 5k? He’s not going to go buy more than a few billion in shares of Apple/MSFT, etc. with that money. He doesn’t ever want to hold over 10% positions in publicly traded companies for disclosure reasons. His game at this size is waiting for attractive companies to be in need. What company that was attractive in late March was in desperate need of capital? How quickly do you think Berk can negotiate a full on takeover? 

He’s in a waiting game. This thing is far from over. He’s not a hedge fund manager buying temporary market dips.

author: inlandempirestartup
body: If you buy puts, it will go up. If you buy calls, it will go down. If you strangle it, it will bounce between the two strikes. If you straddle it, it will settle a cent or two above your call strike price and you’ll be assigned your shares at a penny discount but the stonk will go down before you can sell it. You’ll decide to run the wheel and sell calls but the losses are greater than your gains. You’ll baghold and the company will claim bankruptcy. Once they claim bankruptcy, they will inevitably wipe out shareholders, you included, so you sell your shares to try and yolo your way back with whatever you have left. When they re-emerge from bankruptcy, they will pay a special dividend to the previous shareholders but you won’t get it because you sold prior to the hold date. Your wife will leave her boyfriend for a man that’s more manly that he could ever be. You’ll jerk off your wife’s ex while you both watch her fuck her new boyfriend. She’ll get pregnant, have the baby, go out for a pack of cigarettes, never come back, divorce you, make you pay alimony AND child support even though you have full custody, just not in the courts eyes. You’ll raise the child, his first words will be “dada”, you’ll teach him to walk, ride a bicycle, throw a baseball, how to ask a girl out, teach him to shave, tie a tie, he will excel in his studies, go to Harvard, graduate at the top of his class. The child, now a man, got an internship after college at Twitter (TWTR) and worked his way up to become CEO, he reorganized the company and it excels beyond your wildest imagination. Every move he makes has the midias touch, he will be featured on every financial news outlet, you’ll see his face plastered all over wall street and main street. Your Tendy alert goes off every day, like clockwork, showing that TWTR has increased more than 5% for the day (it never goes down), the stonk will eclipse the values of Apple, Microsoft and Amazon with retard strength even when the financials don’t make sense. You’ll be proud and everyone around you, no matter where you are, will constantly praise you for his success (which is your success). You alone raised him and he grew up to be everything you wanted, but could never, be. He has always loved you unconditionally, but, since you secretly despised him, you never bought calls, only puts. What I’m trying to say is, buy puts.

author: caedin8
body:
What you are missing is NVDA's economic moat in the machine learning world. 

All the software runs on CUDA. The software stack that enables the AI revolution is what is going to put NVDA products in every data center for the ongoing future.

I am a machine learning engineer and everything I use runs on CUDA. Being the backbone behind the AI revolution over the next 10 years is going to be extremely profitable for NVDA, just like the Windows OS made Microsoft the biggest home computer company, and iOS made Apple the biggest phone company.

author: TeetsMcGeets23
body:
Or one man’s investment is another man’s investment is another man’s investment is another man’s investment, etc. 

If there is a group of people/corporations that don’t have a need for actual capital assets and have their operating expenses covered, and are basically in a long circle jerk of investment into each other’s companies that don’t actually need money, eventually, it may hit an end point such as Apple, who choose to sit on it. If we continue to inject money into this circle jerk to keep pushing their investment prices up we aren’t really doing much but inflating their stock value. 

That is why the velocity of money is decreasing. There are end-points in our economy where growth is redundant and a stopping point makes logical strategic sense, so they can wait for the next ubiquitous opportunity which will require a massive amount of capital (such as an M&A.)

author: SweetJackal
body:
To put it simply, you are thinking that a dollar is worth a dollar, which is wrong.  A dollar is worth what you can trade for it.

If we look back into 2017 and 2019 territory we see a strong market, an economy marked by low unemployment and high demand for skilled labor while also increasing GDP, and strong fundamentals from the stars of the market with improving metrics in the lower ends.  In short, a reflection of a golden age for the market that had built up over time.

Yet, though the economy is shot and those strong fundamentals are now taking on water, that the gold has turned to lead, the prices are once again high.

The value of the stocks themselves aren't as high as they were before rather the money you are trading with doesn't have the same value in the market itself.  Central banks buying up high risk assets (junk bonds, corporate bonds, ETFs, at risk mortgages) combined with the restriction on discretionary spending from the closure of entertainment centers driving gamblers into the stock market, the collapse of the bond attraction from Trump promoting negative rates and negate rates appearing on the global scale, and the investors following the federal example of Stonks Only Go Up is pushing a multiple of the spending into the stock exchanges, driving up demand for these equities.

The value of Apple today is less than what it was years ago, however it's price had recovered because the value of the dollar it is compared against has tanked within the perception driven pocket reality of the exchanges.  This is what economists are talking about when they say these are becoming fake markets, they are acting independent of the governing factors of the economy, the market, and the underlying backing due to outside intervention manipulating the exchange.

In the short term the damage to the economy will likely cause deflation in the consumer markets regardless of the money dumps into the exchanges but if a correction or stagnation isn't experienced to allow the consumer markets to recover to the same level then we will experience aggressive inflation in the consumer markets in the long term that will dramatically outpace wage increases due to selling of exchange assets moving the money from the exchanges into the consumer markets.

TLDR: I am a literal autist, and things only make sense if you realize that it isn't that a cup of coffee is worth a dollar, it is that a dollar is only worth a cup of coffee.  And tomorrow a dollar will be worth less than a cup of coffee.

author: Dreadpiratemarc
body:
How many of the original DJIA are still in business?  I think it's maybe just GE and ATT.  All the rest, industry giants in their day, have dissolved.  Businesses like everything else have a life cycle.  

How many of the tech darlings popular with amature investors do you think will still be a good investment in 30 years?  Microsoft and Apple might or might not.  But Facebook?  Netflix?  Definitely not.  Amazon will probably be around but it will be more like Walmart is today, struggling to find growth in a saturated market and facing disruptors of its own.

author: poopa_scoopa
body:
[https://www.inc.com/glenn-leibowitz/apple-ceo-tim-cook-this-is-number-1-reason-we-make-iphones-in-china-its-not-what-you-think.html](https://www.inc.com/glenn-leibowitz/apple-ceo-tim-cook-this-is-number-1-reason-we-make-iphones-in-china-its-not-what-you-think.html)   


Tim Cook on China a few years ago...

"There's a confusion about China. The popular conception is that companies come to China because of low labor cost. I'm not sure what part of China they go to but the truth is China stopped being the low labor cost country many years ago. And that is not the reason to come to China from a supply point of view. The reason is because of the skill, and the quantity of skill in one location and the type of skill it is."

And China has an abundance of skilled labor unseen elsewhere, says Cook:

"The products we do require really advanced tooling, and the precision that you have to have, the tooling and working with the materials that we do are state of the art. And the tooling skill is very deep here. In the US you could have a meeting of tooling engineers and I'm not sure we could fill the room. In China you could fill multiple football fields."

Cook credits China's vast supply of highly skilled vocational talent:

"The vocational expertise is very very deep here, and I give the education system a lot of credit for continuing to push on that even when others were de-emphasizing vocational. Now I think many countries in the world have woke up and said this is a key thing and we've got to correct that. China called that right from the beginning."

&#x200B;

I think this will be hard for India to replicate....

author: SwanArmy
body:
I'm gonna drastically simplify this for you, keep in mind that this isn't the actual definition of IV by any means.

Essentially, Implied Volatility is an options term for how much the underlying stock will move in a given time frame. Since TSLA has much wider swings in stock price than say...AAPL or MSFT, TSLA has higher IV. This higher IV correlates to lower movement in options prices for large moves. For example, a 5% move in TSLA will result in 50-60% gains in TSLA at-the-money options, but a 5% move in MSFT will translate to 150-200% gains in MSFT at-the-money options.

TSLA is expected to move let's say....5 percent per day. It's NOT expected to move 5% in an hour. That's what i meant in that in general, TSLA's stock price was moving a lot more than expected (on high volume) during that timeframe.
